text:
I know English is the number 1 universal language in the world & I'm British BUT English isn't my real native language/first language. I was born in England but moved to France when I was 3, so I didn't attend any schools, colleges or uni in England therefore it's impossible to learn all the English words by attending nursery! . Also I spent most of my time sleeping & not listening to the teacher when I was at school üòÑ.

 So that explains why I'm not fluent in English, It also explains why I make spelling mistakes when I write in English ( for example how can you tell the difference between then & than? Or whether embarrassing is spelt "embarassing" or "embarrasing"  It's basic mistakes like that that can't be solved by watching tv series,films) My grammar/vocabulary is not 100% correct how could it be if I left England when I was 3? 

Also I didn't attend primary school, nor did I attend any high school, college, 6th form, grammar secondary school so that explains why I'm worse at writing in English than speaking it. And why I make mistakes in grammer/vocabulary üòä


As for speaking English, it's normal I'm not 100% fluent, there are a few words that I stilll don't know, especially some English dialects such as some scouse or cockney expressions/slang words, how am I supposed to know them if I grew up in France? 

Not to mention the English classes I had at school/college in France were just basic English ( no wonder the French/Italians suck at speaking English üòÇ) & back then from 2000-2007 the English taught at school was very basic compared to nowadays. Also I didn't take any English classes outside of school so all the English I've learnt is from watching TV & listening to music!Ôªø

text: I think that reading English books can help you improve your writing, reading, and speaking skills but it has nothing to do with improving your pronunciation. text: The narrator is fluent, his pronunciation is clear. He does not quite sound native. However, always remember: you may learn stategies for increasing your proficiency from a non-native, strategies that a native speaker may never have thought of! Therefore, do not discount the ideas of an extremely proficient  non-native. Also, practice in Front of a mirror can help: you can overcome shyness, observe your facial expressions, Position of the mouth in forming words, etc. By the way, the suggestions in this video really work: I did it with German and French as  I was learning, before anyone made a video or even suggested this method! I am glad someone cared to put these suggestions out on YouTube. Well done!!!Ôªø

text: It is Not a question of accent. He speaks English fluently, without hesitation. His grammar is excellent, and his pronunciation is clear enough. The former Secretary of State in the UDA, Dr. Henry Kissinger, has a rather head accent, comparitively speaking. I as a native s√ºesker, would not hesitated to ask him a question about proper usage of any word or expression. Dou completely missed the point of this presentation, and that is indeed unfortunate. Watch again, this time without any prejudice or preconceived notions: it is a Strategy that works for bin native speakers to learn to speak without hesitating as much. He did not make any Promise about a perfect accent, and fluency does not mean a perfect accent, rather merely that one can be easily understood and can speak in a flowing, connected M√§nner. Have a nice day.Ôªø

text: If you don't have anybody to speak with, well even if you have such person, I'd strongly recommend to record yourself while speaking or retelling stuff. Then listen to yourself and you will finally be able to see  the most persistent mistakes in grammar, intonation and lexicon and to be mindful of them during the next speaking session. It's like becoming  your own tutor. However unpleasant for some the experience of listening their own voice may be, it has proven to be the most effective tactics for many people.Ôªø

author: ethan santiago

text:
Apart from reading and watching english materials, I would say that listening to english songs and singing to them helped me a lot when I was young. Music helps with the correct pronunciation, varying my tones and rhythm while at the same time practicing my breathing to be more relaxed. The effect of music to your mood also adds to the fun way of improving my english.

If I wanted more challenge, I'd pick up a fast-tempo songs, borderline rap, or just try to pick up the song lyrics that I've never heard before and memorizing them soon after. With english, its not the speed of your speech that's important in communication, rather its how well one is able to converse as natural and casual so that the other person may understood you better. Furthermore, if you're able to speak in a more relaxed tempo and manner, you're able to sync your thoughts at the same pace as your speech is.Ôªø

author: Ha Lin

text: Chen Kevin.. Hi there man!!  I think that writing down all the things you hear it's going to help you in grammar, more than speaking. I believe that if you want to become more fluent orally  you have to listen to the language and then produce sentences,  could be the same sentences you heard or new ones. To write better you have to read more and then  write down things,  but to speak better you have to listen and speak more and more without "thinking"  just let the language become part of you and get immersed/submerged  in it.. author: Lader TD

text:
So your problem is that you know the words but you often don't know how to pronounce them, and that causes you to hesitate when talking, right?

The best way to solve this problem (in my view) is basic imitation (link below):
English Speaking Practice (very easy to do)

After doing the exercise consistently for a while, your brain will learn how to convert words into the right sequence of mouth movements. And that's how you improve :)Ôªø
